Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Story: I was just finishing my shift at the pool when I got a text from Mark, someone I know from my old college class. He sounded desperate—he was moving apartments today and his help had bailed. “Can you come by? Just need a hand with a few boxes,” he wrote. As an acquaintance, I felt that tug of obligation; I knew how stressful moving could be, and I didn’t want to let him down. But as I was locking up, I noticed the lane rope in the main pool was snapped, floating limply in the water. Swim lessons were scheduled in less than an hour, and as the lifeguard on duty, it was my responsibility to make sure all equipment was safe and ready. If I left now, the lessons might be delayed or unsafe. If I stayed, Mark would be left stranded, maybe thinking I didn’t care. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I stood there, phone in hand, heart pounding, torn between two roles that suddenly felt impossible to balance.
